questions.text: Lack of differentiation is called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anaplasia Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation and structural organization in cells, making them appear primitive or undifferentiated. This lack of differentiation is a hallmark of malignant tumors. Anaplastic cells typically have irregular shapes, larger nuclei, and increased mitotic activity, which are features associated with aggressive cancer behavior. These cells lose their specialized functions and revert to an undifferentiated state, indicating a high degree of malignancy. Why the other options are incorrect: (B) Metaplasia: Metaplasia is the reversible transformation of one type of differentiated cell into another type of differentiated cell, usually as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation. For example, the replacement of normal columnar epithelial cells with squamous cells in the respiratory tract of smokers. Unlike anaplasia, metaplasia involves a change in cell type rather than a loss of differentiation. (C) Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal growth and development of cells, often marked by variations in cell size, shape, and organization. It is a precursor to malignancy but does not imply a complete loss of differentiation, as seen in anaplasia. Dysplastic changes can sometimes regress if the underlying cause is removed. (D) Carcinoma: Carcinoma is a type of malignant tumor derived from epithelial cells. While anaplasia is a characteristic feature of carcinoma, not all carcinomas are entirely undifferentiated. Carcinoma is a broader term describing a category of cancers, while anaplasia specifically denotes the degree of undifferentiation in the cells.

questions.text: C-KIT mutations are seen in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). C-KIT mutations are commonly associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). The C-KIT gene encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase (CD117), which plays a crucial role in cell signaling, proliferation, and survival. Mutations in C-KIT lead to the constitutive activation of this receptor, promoting tumorigenesis. The majority of GISTs (approximately 75-85%) exhibit activating mutations in the C-KIT gene, making it a key diagnostic and therapeutic target. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is particularly effective in treating GISTs with C-KIT mutations, further underscoring the clinical significance of this genetic alteration. Why the other options are incorrect: (B) Ovarian cancers: C-KIT expression has been observed in some ovarian cancers, but C-KIT mutations are not a common or defining feature of these tumors. The genetic alterations in ovarian cancers typically involve genes like BRCA1, BRCA2, and TP53 rather than C-KIT. (C) Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma, a cancer of the sympathetic nervous system, is more commonly associated with genetic changes such as MYCN amplification and ALK mutations. C-KIT mutations are not a hallmark of neuroblastoma. (D) Small-cell carcinoma of the lung: Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with alterations in genes like TP53, RB1, and MYC family genes. While C-KIT expression has been noted in some cases, mutations in the C-KIT gene are not characteristic of this type of cancer

questions.text: Overgrowth of a bile duct at localized region is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hamartoma Hamartoma is a mass of disorganized tissue indigenous to the particular site, such as the lung or the liver. While traditionally considered developmental malformations, many hamartomas have clonal chromosomal aberrations that are acquired through somatic mutations and on this basis are now considered to be neoplastic

questions.text: Which of the following mutation is seen in Cowden syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PTEN: • Encodes a lipid phosphatase which is an important negative regulator of PI3K/ AKT pathway • Germline LoF mutations in Cowden syndrome PTCH1 • Encodes membrane receptor that is a negative regulator of Hedgehog signalling pathway • Germline LoF cause Gorlin syndrome associated with high risk of basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma STK11 • Serine threonine kinase 11 • Peutz Jegher syndrome SMAD4 • Signal transduction protein of TGF beta pathway • Pancreatic cancer • Juvenile polyposis

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2
Cell cycle will stop at G1
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.text: If the RB gene phosphorylation is defective which of the following will happen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

questions.text: E6 protein of high risk human papilloma viruses bind to the following protein and there by promotes carcinogenesis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) TP53. The E6 protein of high-risk human papillomaviruses (HPVs), such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, plays a significant role in promoting carcinogenesis by targeting the tumor suppressor protein TP53 for degradation. E6 binds to TP53 and recruits E6-associated protein (E6AP), an E3 ubiquitin ligase, leading to ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation of TP53. The loss of TP53 function disrupts cell cycle control, apoptosis, and genomic stability, allowing abnormal cells to survive and proliferate. This mechanism is a critical step in HPV-mediated carcinogenesis, particularly in cervical cancer. Why the other options are incorrect: (A) RB: Although HPV contributes to RB inactivation, this function is mediated by the E7 protein, not E6. E7 binds to and inactivates RB, releasing E2F transcription factors and promoting uncontrolled cell cycle progression. E6 specifically targets TP53, making this option incorrect in the context of E6. (C) APC: The APC gene (adenomatous polyposis coli) is a tumor suppressor involved in the regulation of the Wnt signaling pathway and is commonly mutated in colorectal cancer. APC is not a target of the E6 protein, making this option incorrect. (D) MDM2: MDM2 is an endogenous regulator of TP53 that ubiquitinates TP53 for degradation under normal conditions. While MDM2 and E6 both target TP53, MDM2 is not directly involved in HPV-related carcinogenesis. The E6 protein promotes TP53 degradation independently of MDM2, rendering this option incorrect.

questions.text: All are associated with BRCA mutation except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Endometrial carcinoma Although the precise causes are not known, a link with certain variants of BRCA1/2 has been described. [3] Furthermore, women with BRCA1/2 mutation have a 5% risk of developing primary peritoneal cancer even after prophylactic oophorectomy. Primary peritoneal carcinoma shows similar rates of tumor suppressor gene dysfunction (p53, BRCA, WT1) as ovarian cancer and can also show an increased expression of HER-2/neu.

questions.text: BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 genes are located on chromosomes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 17 and 13. The BRCA1 gene is located on chromosome 17q21, while the BRCA2 gene is located on chromosome 13q12.3. Both genes are tumor suppressor genes that play critical roles in DNA repair via homologous recombination. Mutations in these genes lead to a loss of function, increasing the risk of developing hereditary cancers, particularly breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers. Knowing the chromosomal locations of BRCA1 and BRCA2 is crucial for genetic testing, counseling, and understanding their role in hereditary cancer syndromes. Why the other options are incorrect: (A) 17 and 22: While BRCA1 is indeed located on chromosome 17, chromosome 22 does not host the BRCA2 gene. This option is incorrect because BRCA2 is located on chromosome 13. (B) 13 and 17: This option lists the correct chromosomes for the BRCA genes but reverses the order of their conventional listing. The standard notation places BRCA1 on chromosome 17 and BRCA2 on chromosome 13, making this answer incorrect as presented. (D) 13 and 22: Chromosome 13 hosts the BRCA2 gene, but chromosome 22 does not host BRCA1. This pairing does not correspond to the correct chromosomal locations of BRCA1 and BRCA2, making it incorrect.

questions.text: Gene promoting metastasis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Among candidates for metastasis oncogenes, best recognised are SNAIL andTWIST, which encode transcription factors whose primary function is to promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). In EMT, carcinoma cells downregulate certain epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and upregulate certain mesenchymal markers (e.g., vimentin and smooth muscle actin). These changes are believed to favor the development of a promigratory phenotype that is essential for metastasis. Loss of E-cadherin expression seems to be a key event in EMT, and SNAIL and TWIST are transcriptional repressors that downregulate E-cadherin expression. EMT has been documented mainly in breast cancers; whether it is a general phenomenon MET (mesenchymal to epithelial transition) is seen at the site of metastatic tumor seeding where epithelial markers are again up regulated for cell-to-cell adhesion.

questions.text: Excessive fibrosis in a tumor in called:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Desmoplasia In some tumors, connective tissue is scant and so the neoplasm is soft and fleshy. In other cases, the parenchymal cells stimulate the formation of an abundant collagenous stroma, referred to as desmoplasia. Some demoplastic tumors—for example, some cancers of the female breast—are stony hard or scirrhous

questions.text: Chromothrypsis mechanism of carcinogenesis has been found to be associated with which of the following tumors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Osteosarcoma The true extent of chromosome rearrangements in cancer is only now coming into view thanks to sequencing of entire cancer cell genomes, which allows for comprehensive “reconstruction” of chromosomes from DNA sequences. Genomic sequencing has revealed not only many simple rearrangements (e.g., small deletions, duplications, or inversions) that were not appreciated by prior methods, but also much more dramatic chromosome “catastrophes” termed chromothrypsis (literally, chromosome shattering). Chromothrypsis is observed in 1% to 2% of cancers as a whole, but is found in up to 25% of osteosarcomas and other bone cancers and at relatively high frequency in gliomas as well. It appears to result from a single event in which dozens to hundreds of chromosome breaks occur within part or across the entirety of a single chromosome or several chromosomes

questions.text: In tumor lysis syndrome, all of the following are seen except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypercalcemia. Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) occurs when a large number of tumor cells break down rapidly, releasing their intracellular contents into the bloodstream. This condition is commonly seen after the initiation of chemotherapy or other treatments in cancers with high cell turnover, such as leukemias and lymphomas. TLS is characterized by hyperuricemia (due to DNA breakdown into uric acid), hyperkalemia (due to the release of intracellular potassium), and hyperphosphatemia (due to the release of intracellular phosphate). However, calcium binds to the excess phosphate in the blood, resulting in hypocalcemia rather than hypercalcemia. Thus, hypercalcemia is not seen in TLS. Why the other options are incorrect: (A) Hyperuricemia: The breakdown of large numbers of tumor cells releases nucleic acids, which are metabolized into uric acid. Elevated uric acid levels in the blood (hyperuricemia) can lead to kidney injury, a hallmark of TLS. (C) Hyperkalemia: Potassium is an abundant intracellular ion, and its release into the bloodstream following massive tumor cell lysis leads to hyperkalemia. This can cause severe complications, including cardiac arrhythmias. (D) Hyperphosphatemia: Tumor cells release large amounts of phosphate upon lysis, leading to hyperphosphatemia. Elevated phosphate levels can contribute to calcium-phosphate precipitation and kidney damage.

questions.text: A surgeon suspecting testicular carcinoma in a patient asks the intern to send the sample for histopathology, what is the fluid in which the intern should send the sample to the pathologist?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bouin solution Fixatives used in pathology 1. Histopathology routine- 10% neutral buffered formalin (most commonly used fixative) 2. Electron microscopy- glutaraldehyde 3. Testicular biopsies- Bouin’s fluid (can be used for GIT and endocrine too) 4. Lymph node/bone marrow/kidney-Zenker’s (good nuclear details) or B5 5. To dissolve fat for lymph node examination in radical resections-Carnoy’s (also for karyotyping) 6. Cytopathology - Ethanol (95%)

questions.text: Tumor markers and tumors-find the wrong match:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Desmin-Carcinoma. Desmin is an intermediate filament protein that is specifically expressed in muscle cells and is a tumor marker for tumors of muscle origin, such as rhabdomyosarcomas (skeletal muscle) and leiomyosarcomas (smooth muscle). It is not associated with carcinomas, which are epithelial in origin. Tumor markers for carcinomas typically include cytokeratins or epithelial membrane antigen (EMA). Thus, pairing desmin with carcinoma is incorrect. Why the other options are correct: (B) Vimentin-sarcoma: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein expressed in mesenchymal cells and serves as a marker for tumors of mesenchymal origin, such as sarcomas. Sarcomas arise from connective tissue, including bone, muscle, and fat, making vimentin a reliable marker for these tumors. (C) Leucocyte specific antigen-lymphoma: Leucocyte-specific antigens, such as CD45, are expressed on white blood cells and are used as markers for lymphoid neoplasms, including lymphomas. CD45 is particularly useful in distinguishing lymphomas from other types of tumors. (D) S100-melanoma: S100 protein is a well-known marker for melanomas. It is expressed in neural crest-derived cells, including melanocytes. S100 is also used as a diagnostic marker for other tumors, such as schwannomas and Langerhans cell histiocytosis, but it is most prominently associated with melanoma

questions.text: All of the following viruses have been implicated in causation of hematolymphoid neoplasms except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CMV Three lymphotropic viruses—human T-cell leukemia virus-1 (HTLV-1), Epstein- Barr virus (EBV), and Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus/human herpesvirus-8 (KSHV/HHV-8)—have been implicated as causative agents in particular lymphomas. HTLV-1 is associated with adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma. EBV is found in a subset of Burkitt lymphoma, 30% to 40% of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL), many B-cell lymphomas arising in the setting of T-cell immunodeficiency, and rare NK-cell lymphomas. In addition to Kaposi sarcoma. KSHV is associated with an unusual B-cell lymphoma that presents as a malignant effusion, often in the pleural cavity

questions.text: A 45-year man presents a cervical lymphadenopathy, biopsy from the lesion closely adhesive neoplastic cells forming glands. A suspicion of metastatic adenocarcinoma was made. Further imaging and investigations does not reveal any possible primary. A further Immunohistochemistry shows CK7+, CK20- . Which of the following organs is most likely organ for such a primay
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lung. In cases of metastatic adenocarcinoma, immunohistochemistry (IHC) is used to identify the tissue of origin. The CK7 and CK20 expression profile is critical in narrowing down the primary site. CK7+ (cytokeratin 7 positive) and CK20- (cytokeratin 20 negative) are typically associated with adenocarcinomas originating from the lung, breast, or upper gastrointestinal tract. In this patient, cervical lymphadenopathy suggests a thoracic or nearby source, and lung adenocarcinoma is the most likely primary given the IHC profile and clinical presentation. Imaging studies might fail to reveal a primary lesion due to its small size or the metastatic nature of the disease. Why the other options are incorrect: (B) Liver: Primary liver cancers, such as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), typically do not express CK7 or CK20. Instead, they are more commonly associated with markers like HepPar1 and AFP (alpha-fetoprotein). Liver metastases from other primaries may express CK7 or CK20 depending on the source, but liver itself is unlikely to be the primary site in this case. (C) Colon: Colorectal adenocarcinomas are typically CK7- and CK20+ in IHC profiling, which is the opposite of the observed pattern in this patient (CK7+ and CK20-). This makes the colon an unlikely primary site for the metastatic disease described. (D) Prostate: Prostate adenocarcinoma does not typically express CK7 or CK20. Instead, it is characterized by specific markers such as PSA (prostate-specific antigen) and PSAP (prostate-specific acid phosphatase). The IHC profile in this case does not support a prostate origin.

questions.text: Which of the following cyclins propels cell from G2 --> M phase
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cyclin B. Cyclin B, in association with cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (CDK1), forms the mitosis-promoting factor (MPF), which is essential for driving the cell from the G2 phase into the M phase (mitosis). Cyclin B-CDK1 activity regulates the condensation of chromatin, breakdown of the nuclear envelope, and formation of the mitotic spindle. Cyclin B levels increase during the G2 phase and peak during the M phase, ensuring the cell transitions properly into mitosis. Why the other options are incorrect: (B) Cyclin D: Cyclin D associates with CDK4 and CDK6 and is primarily involved in the G1 phase, helping the cell transition from G1 to the S phase. It does not play a direct role in the G2 to M phase transition. (C) Cyclin A: Cyclin A functions in both the S phase and G2 phase by associating with CDK2 and CDK1. It plays a role in DNA replication and preparing the cell for mitosis, but it does not directly control the transition into the M phase. (D) Cyclin E: Cyclin E associates with CDK2 and is crucial for the G1 to S phase transition, where it helps initiate DNA replication. It is not involved in the G2 to M phase transition.

questions.text: Philadephia chromosome seen in chronic myeloid leukemia produces a protein called
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) P210. The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates a fusion gene, BCR-ABL1, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase protein. The most common form of the BCR-ABL1 protein produced in CML is P210, named for its molecular weight of approximately 210 kDa. This protein drives uncontrolled cell proliferation and resistance to apoptosis, key features of CML pathogenesis. Why the other options are incorrect: (A) P170: P170 is associated with P-glycoprotein, a product of the MDR1 (multi-drug resistance) gene, which is involved in drug resistance in cancer cells. It is unrelated to the Philadelphia chromosome or CML. (C) P190: The P190 form of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein is typically seen in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) rather than CML. This variant results from a different breakpoint in the BCR gene and has distinct biological and clinical implications. (D) P230: The P230 form of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein is rare and associated with chronic neutrophilic leukemia (CNL) or atypical CML, not the classic CML seen with the P210 variant.

questions.text: Loss of which of the following protein is implicated in aiding metastasis of tumor cells?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cadherins Integrins are components of ECM which help in binding of cells to ECM. Although implicated in metastasis, E and N cadherins (part of desmosomes) are more recognised in the mechanism of invasion of metastasis, the former, when lost, playing a role in epithelial-mesenchymal transition. Matrix metalloproteases and cathepsin help breakdown stroma and aid invasion. Loss of E cadherin is also characteristically noted in Lobular carcinoma breast and diffuse gastric carcinoma.

choices.text: Endometrial cancer is the most common extra colonic tumor involved

questions.text: All of the following points are true about Lynch syndrome except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Left colon is involved more Warthin Lynch syndrome or Hereditary non polyposis coli cancer is the most common familial cause of colorectal carcinoma. Patients affected are younger and usually involve the right colon. Mucinous, signet ring cell features are more common and intra tumoral lymphocytes are increased. Increased incidence of other cancers like endometrial (most common), gastric, ovarian and transitional cell is also noted.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable feature of malignancy in a paraganglioma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Presence of metastasis. Paragangliomas are neuroendocrine tumors arising from extra-adrenal paraganglia. Determining malignancy in paragangliomas is challenging because histological features such as nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, or capsular invasion are not definitive indicators of malignancy. The most reliable feature of malignancy in a paraganglioma is the presence of metastasis, which is defined as tumor spread to non-primary sites, such as lymph nodes, bone, liver, or lung. Metastasis confirms the tumor’s ability to invade and spread, making it a clear indicator of malignancy. Why the other options are incorrect: (B) Nuclear pleomorphism: Nuclear pleomorphism refers to variation in the size and shape of nuclei, which can be seen in both benign and malignant paragangliomas. It is not a reliable indicator of malignancy because it can occur in non-malignant tumors as well. (C) Vascular or capsular invasion: While vascular or capsular invasion suggests aggressive behavior, it is not specific or sufficient to classify a paraganglioma as malignant. Benign tumors can also exhibit these features without progressing to malignancy. (D) Increased mitotic activity: Although increased mitotic activity can indicate a high proliferative rate, it is not definitive for malignancy in paragangliomas. Many benign paragangliomas may exhibit some mitotic activity without metastasizing.

choices.text: Driver mutations in KRAS are seen in follicular carcinoma
BRAF mutations are the most common mutations seen in papillary carcinoma
RET rearrangements are seen in medullary carcinoma
PI3K mutations are seen in anaplastic carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding genetics of thyroid tumors
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) RET rearrangements are seen in medullary carcinoma. This statement is incorrect because RET rearrangements are primarily associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC), not medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). RET/PTC rearrangements occur in about 20-40% of papillary carcinomas and are key drivers of tumorigenesis. In contrast, medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with germline or somatic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, not rearrangements, and is often part of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, particularly MEN2A and MEN2B. Why the other options are correct: (A) Driver mutations in KRAS are seen in follicular carcinoma: KRAS mutations, along with mutations in NRAS and HRAS, are frequently found in follicular thyroid carcinomas. These mutations are part of the RAS signaling pathway and contribute to the tumor's progression and invasion. (B) BRAF mutations are the most common mutations seen in papillary carcinoma: BRAF mutations, particularly the BRAF V600E mutation, are the most common genetic alteration in papillary thyroid carcinoma. They are present in up to 45% of PTC cases and are associated with poor prognostic features such as extrathyroidal extension and lymph node metastases. (D) PI3K mutations are seen in anaplastic carcinoma: Mutations in the PI3K/AKT pathway, along with alterations in TP53 and TERT promoter mutations, are commonly seen in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. These mutations drive the highly aggressive nature of anaplastic carcinoma.

questions.text: All are markers for malignant melanoma except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) SOX 11 SOX11 is not a marker for malignant melanoma. It is a transcription factor primarily associated with central nervous system development and is used diagnostically in certain tumors, such as mantle cell lymphoma and some soft tissue tumors. It has no role in identifying or diagnosing malignant melanoma, making it the incorrect option in this context. Why the other options are correct: (A) HMB 45: HMB 45 (Human Melanoma Black 45) is a specific marker for melanocytic differentiation. It is widely used in the diagnosis of malignant melanoma as it identifies premelanosome antigens present in melanoma cells. (B) MART1: MART1 (Melanoma Antigen Recognized by T-cells 1), also known as Melan-A, is another highly specific marker for melanocytic tumors, including malignant melanoma. It is commonly used in immunohistochemistry to confirm melanocytic origin. (D) SOX 10: SOX10 is a transcription factor expressed in neural crest-derived cells, including melanocytes. It is a sensitive marker for melanocytic tumors and is used to confirm the diagnosis of melanoma, especially in challenging cases.

questions.text: All are true about aflatoxin except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aflatoxin B3 mostly implicated Because of their chemical structures, some carcinogens interact preferentially with particular DNA sequences or bases, and thus produce mutations that are clustered at “hotspots” or that are enriched for particular base substitutions. One illustrative example of a chemical carcinogen associated with a mutational “hotspot” is aflatoxin B1, a naturally occurring agent produced by some strains of a mold called Aspergillus. Aspergillus grows on improperly stored grains and nuts, and there is a strong correlation between the dietary level of this food contaminant and the incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma in parts of Africa and the Far East. Interestingly, aflatoxin B1 -associated hepatocellular carcinomas tend to have a particular mutation in TP53, a G : C?T : A transversion in codon 249 that produces an arginine to serine substitution in the p53 protein. In contrast, TP53 mutations are infrequent in liver tumors from areas where aflatoxin contamination of food does not occur, and few of these mutations involve codon 249. Similarly, lung cancers associated with smoking have a 10-fold higher mutational burden on average than lung cancers in nonsmokers, and these excess mutations are strongly skewed toward particular base substitutions known to be caused by carcinogens in cigarette smoke (the proverbial “smoking gun”).

questions.text: Which of the following Is the most implicated in causation of cutaneous cancers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) UVB The UV portion of the solar spectrum can be divided into three wavelength ranges: UVA (320-400 nm), UVB (280- 320 nm), and UVC (200-280 nm). Of these, UVB is believed to be responsible for the induction of cutaneous cancers. UVC, although a potent mutagen, is not considered significant because it is filtered out by the ozone layer surrounding the earth (hence the concern about ozone depletion). UVB is responsible for production of pyrimidine dimers; which are removed by Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER); defective NER leads to Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP)

questions.text: Epigenetic changes in ARID1A is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ovarian clear cell carcinoma. ARID1A (AT-rich interactive domain-containing protein 1A) is a tumor suppressor gene, and epigenetic changes in this gene are commonly associated with ovarian clear cell carcinoma (OCCC). Loss of ARID1A function due to mutations or epigenetic silencing is a well-known characteristic of OCCC and has been implicated in the tumorigenesis of this particular carcinoma. This mutation contributes to the disruption of chromatin remodeling, which affects cell differentiation and proliferation, playing a key role in the development of ovarian clear cell carcinoma. Therefore, epigenetic changes in ARID1A are most notably seen in ovarian clear cell carcinoma, making option C the correct answer. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia): ARID1A mutations or epigenetic changes are not commonly associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Although epigenetic alterations are a hallmark of various hematologic malignancies, ARID1A mutations have not been prominently linked to AML. Instead, AML is more commonly associated with mutations in genes involved in hematopoiesis and transcription factors (e.g., FLT3, NPM1, and RUNX1). Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Follicular lymphoma: ARID1A mutations or epigenetic changes are not a prominent feature of follicular lymphoma either. Follicular lymphoma is a B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma that typically involves mutations in the BCL2 gene, resulting in an anti-apoptotic effect, as well as changes in other genes involved in cell cycle regulation. ARID1A changes are not a major driver in follicular lymphoma. Thus, this option is incorrect. D. Renal cell carcinoma: ARID1A mutations are not typically associated with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). While RCC has a variety of genetic alterations, including mutations in the VHL gene and alterations in the PI3K/AKT pathway, ARID1A mutations are not a common feature of this cancer. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following gene is translocated in Burkitt lymphoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MYC. Burkitt lymphoma is characterized by a translocation involving the MYC gene. Specifically, the most common translocation is t(8;14)(q24;q32), which results in the MYC gene on chromosome 8 being placed under the control of the IGH (immunoglobulin heavy chain) gene on chromosome 14. This translocation leads to overexpression of MYC, a proto-oncogene that promotes cell growth and proliferation, driving the development of Burkitt lymphoma. The overexpression of MYC is central to the pathogenesis of this aggressive B-cell lymphoma. Therefore, MYC is the correct gene translocated in Burkitt lymphoma. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. PML: The PML gene is involved in the t(15;17) translocation, which is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Burkitt lymphoma. The PML-RARA fusion protein leads to impaired differentiation of promyelocytes, a hallmark of APL. Thus, this option is incorrect. B. FLI1: The FLI1 gene is involved in translocations in certain Ewing sarcomas, typically with the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 (e.g., t(11;22)(q24;q12)). FLI1 translocations are not characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, so this option is incorrect. D. CCND1: The CCND1 gene, which encodes Cyclin D1, is translocated in mantle cell lymphoma, resulting in the overexpression of Cyclin D1. This translocation typically occurs as t(11;14)(q13;q32) and is not a feature of Burkitt lymphoma. Thus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which IHC marker will be useful to distinguish between ALL and thymoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cytokeratin. In order to distinguish between acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and thymoma, the Cytokeratin marker is helpful. Cytokeratins are intermediate filament proteins that are typically expressed in epithelial cells. Thymomas, being epithelial tumors of the thymus, are positive for Cytokeratin on immunohistochemistry (IHC). On the other hand, ALL is a hematologic malignancy that arises from lymphoid precursor cells, and it does not express Cytokeratin. Therefore, Cytokeratin positivity helps in identifying thymoma, while it will be negative in ALL, thus allowing the differentiation between the two. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. TDT (Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase): TDT is an enzyme expressed in immature lymphoid cells, such as precursor T cells and B cells, and it is a marker used to diagnose ALL. While it can be helpful in identifying ALL, it does not help in distinguishing ALL from thymoma, which is epithelial in origin and does not express TDT. Therefore, this option is not correct. B. CD3: CD3 is a marker expressed on T lymphocytes, and it is typically used to identify T-cell malignancies or T-cell markers in IHC. However, thymoma cells are epithelial and may not necessarily express CD3, while ALL, if it involves T-cells, could be CD3-positive. While CD3 is important for T-cell differentiation, it is not specific enough to distinguish ALL from thymoma, making it an incorrect choice. C. CD1a: CD1a is a marker typically used for identifying Langerhans cells and some T-cell malignancies like cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It is not a specific marker for differentiating ALL from thymoma. While it can be positive in some T-cell related conditions, it is not useful in distinguishing these two entities, so this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: Which is not a tumor suppressor gene? (PGI)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) RAS. RAS is an oncogene, not a tumor suppressor gene. Oncogenes are genes that, when mutated or overexpressed, promote the development of cancer. RAS mutations are commonly seen in various cancers, including pancreatic, colorectal, and lung cancer, and lead to uncontrolled cell growth. RAS is involved in signaling pathways that regulate cell division and survival, and mutations often result in the loss of regulatory control, contributing to tumor formation. Therefore, RAS is not classified as a tumor suppressor gene. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. P53: P53 is a classic tumor suppressor gene. It plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle and inducing apoptosis in response to DNA damage. Mutations in p53 are associated with a variety of cancers, as its loss allows damaged cells to continue dividing. Thus, P53 is a tumor suppressor gene and is correct in this context. B. BRCA1: BRCA1 is also a tumor suppressor gene. It is involved in DNA repair, and mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers. The loss of its function can lead to genomic instability, which predisposes cells to tumorigenesis. Therefore, BRCA1 is correctly classified as a tumor suppressor gene. D. PTEN: PTEN is another well-known tumor suppressor gene. It encodes a lipid phosphatase that negatively regulates the PI3K-AKT signaling pathway, which controls cell survival and proliferation. Mutations or deletions in PTEN are associated with several types of cancers, including endometrial, prostate, and glioblastoma. Thus, PTEN is also a tumor suppressor gene.

choices.text: Play major role in cell cycle regulation
Require deletion of both Rb genes

questions.text: All are true regarding Retinoblastoma except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Located on chr 13p 14 In molecular terms, knudson’s hypothesis can be stated as follows: • Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of rb at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma. • In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the rb gene in the germline (the first hit), and the other copy is normal (fig. 7-28). Retinoblastoma develops when the normal rb allele is mutated in retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit). Because such second hits seem to be virtually inevitable in a small fraction of retinoblasts, most individuals inheriting a germline defect in one rb allele develop unilateral or bilateral retinoblastoma, and the disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. • In sporadic cases both normal rb alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits). The probability of this event is low (explaining why retinoblastoma is an uncommon tumor in the general population), but the end result is the same: a retinal cell that has completely lost rb function and becomes cancerous. Note that a child carrying an inherited mutant rb allele In all somatic cells is perfectly normal (except for the increased risk of developing cancer); it follows that One defective rb gene does not affect cell behavior. Thus, while the genetic trait (increased cancer risk) Associated with germline mutations in rb is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, at the level of the Individual cell, lossof-function mutations in the rb gene behave in a recessive fashion.

questions.text: The following protein is called “Gatekeeper of colonic neoplasia”:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) APC. The APC (Adenomatous polyposis coli) protein is often referred to as the "Gatekeeper of colonic neoplasia" because of its critical role in regulating the Wnt signaling pathway, which controls cell growth and differentiation in the colon. APC is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in APC lead to the development of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a condition that predisposes individuals to the formation of multiple colorectal adenomas, which can progress to colorectal cancer. APC serves as a gatekeeper by preventing excessive cell proliferation, making it a key player in preventing colonic neoplasia. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. STK11 (LKB1): STK11 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a serine/threonine kinase involved in regulating cellular energy balance and polarity. Mutations in STK11 are associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which increases the risk of various cancers, including gastrointestinal cancers. However, it is not specifically referred to as the "Gatekeeper of colonic neoplasia," as APC holds this distinction in the context of colorectal cancer. Thus, STK11 is not the correct answer. C. SMAD2: SMAD2 is part of the TGF-? (transforming growth factor-beta) signaling pathway and functions in regulating cell growth and differentiation. Mutations or dysregulation of SMAD2 are associated with various cancers, but it is not particularly associated with the gatekeeper role in colonic neoplasia. Thus, SMAD2 is not the correct answer. D. PTEN: PTEN is another well-known tumor suppressor gene that regulates cell survival and proliferation through the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway. While PTEN mutations are linked to a variety of cancers, including endometrial and prostate cancers, it is not specifically the "Gatekeeper of colonic neoplasia." Therefore, PTEN is not the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: Hall mark mechanism of tumor suppressor gene inactivation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Loss of heterozygosity. The hallmark mechanism of tumor suppressor gene inactivation is loss of heterozygosity (LOH). This refers to the loss of one allele of a tumor suppressor gene, leaving the other allele unaffected but inactive due to a mutation, deletion, or other genetic alteration. In the context of tumor suppressor genes, LOH often results in the loss of the gene’s normal protective function, allowing cells to grow uncontrollably, leading to cancer. LOH is a critical event in the development of many cancers, as it can effectively inactivate a tumor suppressor gene even when the individual carries one normal copy of the gene. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. DNA hypermethylation: DNA hypermethylation refers to the addition of methyl groups to the DNA, usually at CpG islands in gene promoters, which can silence the expression of tumor suppressor genes. While hypermethylation is involved in the inactivation of some tumor suppressor genes, it is not the primary or hallmark mechanism of inactivation. It can contribute to gene silencing but is less commonly associated with tumor suppressor inactivation compared to LOH. C. DNA hypomethylation: DNA hypomethylation refers to the reduction of methyl groups, which may lead to the activation of oncogenes or chromosomal instability. However, hypomethylation is not typically associated with the inactivation of tumor suppressor genes. In fact, hypomethylation is more often linked with the activation of oncogenes and genomic instability, rather than the silencing of tumor suppressor genes. D. Histone deacetylation: Histone deacetylation involves the removal of acetyl groups from histones, leading to a more condensed chromatin structure and the silencing of gene expression. While histone modifications, including deacetylation, can influence gene expression, histone deacetylation is not the hallmark mechanism of tumor suppressor gene inactivation. It can contribute to silencing but is less directly involved in the loss of functional tumor suppressor genes compared to loss of heterozygosity.

questions.text: Dysplasia is characterized by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Invasion. Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal growth and development of cells within tissues, often presenting as a precancerous condition. Key features of dysplasia include an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, loss of architectural structure, and pleomorphism (variation in size and shape of cells and their nuclei). However, invasion is not a characteristic of dysplasia. Invasion refers to the ability of cells to penetrate surrounding tissues, which is a feature of malignant tumors (cancer), not dysplasia. In dysplasia, although the cells may show abnormal features, they do not yet have the invasive potential that would characterize malignancy. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. High nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio: A high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio is a common feature of dysplasia. It means that the nucleus occupies a larger portion of the cell compared to the cytoplasm, which is often a sign of uncontrolled cell growth and abnormal cell division, typical of dysplastic cells. B. Loss of architecture: The loss of architecture refers to the disorganization of the tissue structure, which is a hallmark of dysplasia. In normal tissues, cells are arranged in a specific pattern or architecture, but in dysplasia, this organization is disrupted as cells grow abnormally and lose their normal spatial arrangement. C. Pleomorphism: Pleomorphism is the presence of cells with variations in size and shape, which is often observed in dysplastic tissues. It indicates that the cells are undergoing abnormal growth and differentiation, which is characteristic of dysplasia

questions.text: All of the following are involve in tumor metastasis cascade except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tyrosine kinase. In the tumor metastasis cascade, the process by which cancer cells spread from the primary tumor to other parts of the body, several molecules play crucial roles in enabling the tumor cells to invade, survive, and proliferate in distant tissues. However, tyrosine kinase is not directly involved in the structural or mechanistic aspects of the metastasis cascade. Tyrosine kinases are important for cell signaling and growth factor signaling, but they are not primarily responsible for the physical processes of metastasis. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that plays an essential role in the adhesion of tumor cells to the extracellular matrix (ECM) during metastasis. Tumor cells often interact with fibronectin to anchor themselves in the tissue and to facilitate migration. This makes it an important component in the metastatic cascade. B. E-cadherin: E-cadherin is a cell adhesion molecule that helps cells stick together, maintaining tissue integrity. In the process of metastasis, tumor cells often lose E-cadherin expression, which reduces cell-cell adhesion and allows the cells to dissociate from the primary tumor. This loss is a key step in tumor invasion and metastasis. C. Type IV collagenase: Type IV collagenase (or matrix metalloproteinases like MMPs) plays a crucial role in metastasis by breaking down the extracellular matrix (ECM), particularly type IV collagen. This degradation of the ECM allows tumor cells to invade surrounding tissues and spread to other parts of the body, making it a key player in the metastatic cascade.

questions.text: Human papilloma virus is/are associated with all except: (PGI)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carcinoma pancreas. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is known to be associated with several types of cancers, particularly those in mucosal areas that are subject to sexual contact or viral infection. However, HPV is not typically associated with carcinoma of the pancreas. The pancreas is not a common site of HPV-related tumors, as the virus is primarily linked to cancers of epithelial origin in areas like the cervix, throat, and anal canal. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Oropharyngeal tumors: HPV, particularly types 16 and 18, are strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, including cancers of the tonsils and base of the tongue. These tumors are more common in individuals with oral HPV infections, often linked to sexual transmission. B. Carcinoma nasopharynx: While nasopharyngeal carcinoma is more commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), there is emerging evidence that certain strains of HPV may also play a role in some cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Therefore, HPV can be a contributing factor in a small proportion of these cancers. C. Carcinoma anal canal: HPV is a well-established cause of anal canal carcinoma, particularly in individuals with HIV/AIDS or those who engage in receptive anal intercourse. HPV types 16 and 18 are commonly implicated in the development of this cancer.

questions.text: Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prostate Ca. Migratory thrombophlebitis, also known as Trousseau syndrome, is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with various types of cancer. It is characterized by the formation of blood clots in veins that appear to move from one site to another, typically in superficial veins, and is most frequently seen in malignancies that can provoke a hypercoagulable state. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Lung Ca: Migratory thrombophlebitis is commonly associated with lung cancer, particularly pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The paraneoplastic effect of lung cancer often leads to the production of pro-coagulant substances that increase the risk of thrombosis, leading to migratory thrombophlebitis. C. Colon Ca: Colon cancer can also be associated with migratory thrombophlebitis, likely due to the hypercoagulable state induced by the tumor's secretion of various pro-coagulant factors. This is observed in some patients with colon carcinoma, making it a relevant association with Trousseau syndrome. D. Pancreatic Ca: Pancreatic cancer is one of the classic malignancies associated with Trousseau syndrome. It is well-known for its hypercoagulable state, and patients often present with migratory thrombophlebitis due to the pro-coagulant factors secreted by the tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical marker is positive in neuroendocrine tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Synaptophysin. Synaptophysin is an immunohistochemical marker that is commonly used to identify neuroendocrine tumors. Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from neuroendocrine cells, which are part of the endocrine system and have both hormonal and neural characteristics. Synaptophysin is a protein found in the presynaptic vesicles of neurons and neuroendocrine cells, and it is used as a marker to confirm the presence of neuroendocrine differentiation in tumors. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Cytokeratin: Cytokeratin is a broad marker used to identify epithelial cells and is not specific to neuroendocrine tumors. Although some neuroendocrine tumors may express cytokeratin, it is not a definitive marker for them. Cytokeratin is more commonly used in diagnosing carcinomas of epithelial origin. C. Calretinin: Calretinin is a calcium-binding protein often used to identify mesothelial cells and neurogenic tumors, but it is not as specific for neuroendocrine tumors. It is more commonly used in the diagnosis of mesotheliomas or ovarian tumors. D. GFAP (Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein): GFAP is an intermediate filament protein that is expressed in astrocytes, which are a type of glial cell in the central nervous system. It is used as a marker for gliomas and astrocytic tumors, but it is not associated with neuroendocrine tumors.

questions.text: Fixative agent for PAP smear?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 95% ethanol. In the case of a Papanicolaou (PAP) smear, the standard fixative used is 95% ethanol. Ethanol helps to preserve the cellular details and prevents degradation of the sample, ensuring accurate evaluation of cells under the microscope. It works by precipitating proteins, thereby preserving cell morphology and structure, which is essential for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or malignancy. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. While it can be used to transport samples or rinse slides, it does not preserve cellular structure or prevent degradation of cells like ethanol does. Therefore, saline is not appropriate for the fixation of cells in a PAP smear. B. Formalin: Formalin is a common fixative used in histopathology, but it is not typically used for PAP smears. Formalin is more commonly used in tissue biopsy samples and is unsuitable for smears because it may cause cellular distortion and interfere with the cytological interpretation of smear slides. D. Air drying: Air drying is sometimes used for some cytological preparations, but it is not recommended for PAP smears. Air drying can lead to distortion of cells and loss of diagnostic quality, especially for the preservation of nuclear details. Fixatives like ethanol are preferred because they preserve the integrity of the cells for more accurate analysis.

questions.text: ALK1 mutation seen mc with which hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Type 2. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal blood vessel formation, leading to easy bleeding. It has several types, and mutations in different genes cause these types. Type 2 HHT is most commonly associated with a mutation in the ALK1 gene (Activin receptor-like kinase 1), which encodes a receptor involved in the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-?) signaling pathway. The mutation results in abnormal angiogenesis, leading to the development of arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) and telangiectasias. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Type 1: Type 1 HHT is associated with mutations in the ENG gene (Endoglin), not ALK1. Endoglin is also involved in TGF-? signaling but has a different role than ALK1, so mutations in this gene lead to a different set of vascular abnormalities. C. Type 3: Type 3 HHT is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 gene, which is involved in TGF-? signaling. While this mutation also affects angiogenesis, it is not related to ALK1 mutations. D. Type 4: Type 4 HHT is associated with mutations in the GDF2 gene (Growth differentiation factor 2), which is also involved in the regulation of blood vessel formation, but it is not caused by ALK1 mutations

questions.text: Carbohydrate marker of recurrent breast cancer is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CA 15.3. CA 15.3 is a carbohydrate antigen and is commonly used as a tumor marker for breast cancer. It is especially useful in monitoring the recurrence or progression of breast cancer in patients who have already been diagnosed and treated for the condition. Elevated levels of CA 15.3 may indicate recurrence or metastasis, although it is not specific to breast cancer and can be elevated in other conditions as well. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. CA 125: CA 125 is a tumor marker primarily used to monitor ovarian cancer. It can be elevated in other conditions, such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and some benign ovarian tumors. It is not specific to breast cancer. C. CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen): CEA is a tumor marker used for monitoring colorectal cancer, but it can also be elevated in other malignancies, including breast, lung, and pancreatic cancers. It is not specific for breast cancer recurrence. D. CA 19.9: CA 19.9 is primarily used to monitor pancreatic cancer and some other gastrointestinal cancers, such as cholangiocarcinoma. It is not specific to breast cancer and is not commonly used for detecting or monitoring breast cancer recurrence.

questions.text: AFP and CEA both rise in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Both AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) and CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) can be elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common primary liver cancer. AFP is a specific tumor marker for HCC, and while CEA is not specific for liver cancer, it can be elevated in many gastrointestinal cancers, including HCC. Elevated levels of both AFP and CEA together can indicate the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Testicular tumors: AFP is commonly elevated in non-seminomatous testicular tumors, especially in yolk sac tumors, while CEA is not typically elevated in testicular tumors. Thus, CEA is not a reliable marker for testicular tumors, making this option incorrect. C. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): AFP and CEA are not typically elevated in renal cell carcinoma. While RCC may have a variety of nonspecific markers, AFP and CEA are not among them. This makes RCC an unlikely cause for elevated AFP and CEA. D. Germ cell tumor of the ovary: AFP may be elevated in germ cell tumors of the ovary, particularly in yolk sac tumors, but CEA is not typically associated with these tumors. Therefore, AFP and CEA are not both elevated in this condition, making it incorrect.

questions.text: Grading of cancers does not depend on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Size of primary lesion. Grading of cancers refers to the classification of cancer cells based on their degree of differentiation (how much they resemble normal cells), the number of mitoses (how many cells are dividing), and architectural features (how the cells and tissues are organized). These factors help to determine how aggressive or malignant a cancer is. The size of the primary lesion (the tumor size) is not a factor in grading but is considered in staging, which is a separate system used to determine the extent of cancer spread within the body. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Degree of differentiation: The degree of differentiation is a key factor in cancer grading. Tumors are classified as well-differentiated (resembling normal tissue), moderately differentiated, or poorly differentiated (highly abnormal and more aggressive). B. Number of mitoses: The number of mitoses (how frequently cells divide) is used to grade cancer. Higher mitotic rates often correlate with more aggressive cancer and a worse prognosis. C. Architectural features: The architectural features of a tumor, such as the organization of cancer cells, are also important in grading. Tumors with disrupted architecture are usually considered higher grade, indicating more aggressive behavior.

questions.text: HMB-45 is positive in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - Human Melanoma Black, discovered in 1986 - Common marker to confirm melanoma (invasive melanomas with paradoxical maturation show at least focal deep HMB45 reactivity, in contrast to nevi, which are negative in deep dermis) - Evaluating sentinel lymph nodes for melanoma (Am J Surg Pathol 2001;25:1039) - Diagnosis (or ruling out diagnosis) of perivascular epithelioid cell tumors (angiomyolipoma, lymphangioleiomyomatoisis, PEComa, clear cell "sugar" tumor)

questions.text: An undifferentiated malignant tumor on immuno-histochemical stain shows cytoplasmic positively of most of the tumor cells for cytokeratin. The most probable diagnosis of the tumor is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CK or cytokeratin is the marker for carcinoma, malignancies of epithelial origin CD 45: leucocyte common antigen is the initial marker used to identify lymphomas Vimentin: initial marker used to identify sarcomas (mesenchymal origin) S-100: initial marker used to identify melanomas

questions.text: Which of the following is not premalignant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypertrophy. Hypertrophy refers to the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the organ or tissue. It is usually a physiological response to increased workload or hormonal stimulation, such as muscle hypertrophy due to exercise. It does not involve changes at the cellular level that are associated with cancer risk. Hypertrophy is not considered premalignant. Reasons for Incorrect Options: A. Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia refers to an increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ, leading to its enlargement. While hyperplasia itself is not cancerous, it can be a premalignant condition, as it can sometimes progress to dysplasia and eventually cancer if the underlying stimulus persists. B. Metaplasia: Metaplasia is the reversible replacement of one differentiated cell type with another. Although it is a response to environmental changes (e.g., smoking causing respiratory epithelium to change), metaplasia is considered a premalignant condition, as it can predispose to dysplasia and further progression to cancer. D. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal cell growth with a loss of normal architectural arrangement, size, shape, and orientation of cells. Dysplasia is definitely a premalignant condition and is considered a precursor to cancer in many tissues (e.g., cervical dysplasia).

questions.text: C-KIT mutations are seen in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). C-KIT mutations are commonly associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), which are the most common mesenchymal tumors of the gastrointestinal tract. C-KIT encodes for the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT, which plays a crucial role in the development and survival of GIST cells. Mutations in C-KIT lead to constitutive activation of the KIT receptor, which contributes to the uncontrolled growth of these tumors. Reasons for Incorrect Options: B. Ovarian cancers: Ovarian cancers can involve various genetic mutations, including mutations in BRCA1, BRCA2, and TP53. While some ovarian cancers might show alterations in receptor pathways (such as estrogen or HER2), C-KIT mutations are not commonly associated with ovarian cancers. C. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastomas are childhood tumors that arise from neuroblasts (immature nerve cells). Common genetic mutations in neuroblastoma include MYCN amplification, ALK mutations, and others, but C-KIT mutations are not typically associated with neuroblastoma. D. Small-cell carcinoma of lung: Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor. The common mutations in SCLC include TP53, RB1, and other tumor suppressors, but C-KIT mutations are not a characteristic feature of small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A child with Down’s syndrome presented with increased TLC and anemia. On performing differential count, 65% atypical cells were seen. The diagnosis of AML M7 was rendered. The following morphology in addition to flow cytometry helped in the identification of the condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The megakaryoblasts are usually medium-sized to large blasts (12-18 μm) with a round, slightly irregular, or indented nucleus with fine reticular chromatin and 1-3 nucleoli. The cytoplasm is basophilic, often agranular, and show distinct blebs or pseudopod formation. Option B - ALL (Lymphoblasts) Option C - AML-M3 (Auer rods, Faggot cells, phi bodies) Option D - AML-M5 (Monocytic differentiation)

questions.text: A 56-years-old man presents with complainst of gnawing pain in the mid-epigastrium, with occasional radiation to the back. He also notes a 15-pound weight loss over the past 3 months. The clinician suspects pancreatic carcinoma. Which of the following tumor markers would aid in confirming this diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) Tumor markers can be very helpful in narrowing the possible primary sources for metastatic lesions. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can be seen in any tumor derived from gut epithelium, notably colon cancer and pancreatic cancer. Tumor markers should not be used as the primary tool for cancer diagnosis, but they have considerable utility in reconfirmation of the diagnosis, as well as for monitoring recurrence or response to therapy.

questions.text: A 20-years-old man presents with an enlarged right testicle that was undescended at birth but had self-corrected by age 1. Serum AFP is elevated. A testicular tumor is biopsied and reveals multiple mitoses, along with hemorrhage and necrosis. The surgeon decides to perform an orchiectomy because the tumor type is not particularly radiosensitive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Embryonal carcinoma Embryonal carcinomas occur most commonly in the 20-30 age group and are more aggressive than sminomas. These tumors present with testicular enlargement, and 30% have metastasized at the time of diagnosis. Serum AFP is usually elevatd. They are less radiosensitive than siminomas.

questions.text: A 40-years-old woman comes to the physician for a periodic health maintenance examination. She has no complaints at this time, but she is concerned about a story that she heard on the local news. The story was about that she heard on the local news. The story was about the progeny of women who took diethylstilbestrol (DES) and their increased risk for disease, but she missed the end of the story and is not sure of the disease. This woman is particularly concerned because her mother took DES for the prevention of spontaneous abortion. This woman should be told that she has an increased risk for developing which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma. Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was prescribed to pregnant women in the mid-20th century to prevent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications. Later studies revealed that female offspring (referred to as "DES daughters") exposed to DES in utero have an increased risk of developing vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma. This association is well-documented, and the disease typically presents in young women, often in their teens or early twenties. DES exposure also predisposes these women to other structural abnormalities of the reproductive tract, infertility, and complications during pregnancy. Therefore, informing the patient about her increased risk for this rare but serious condition is critical for appropriate screening and monitoring. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Bladder cancer: Bladder cancer is associated with risk factors such as smoking, exposure to industrial chemicals, and chronic irritation of the bladder. There is no established link between in utero DES exposure and bladder cancer. This choice is incorrect in the context of the patient's concern. B. Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma is most commonly associated with prolonged exposure to unopposed estrogen, obesity, and conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). DES exposure does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer. This makes it an incorrect response. C. Ovarian carcinoma: Ovarian carcinoma is linked to risk factors such as family history, genetic mutations (e.g., BRCA1/BRCA2), and conditions that increase ovulation frequency. DES exposure is not associated with an increased risk of ovarian carcinoma, so this option is also incorrect. D. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma is associated with risk factors such as smoking, obesity, and certain genetic syndromes. There is no evidence linking DES exposure to renal cell carcinoma, making this choice irrelevant to the scenario.

questions.text: A 32-years old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her mother had cervical cancer at age 35, her grand-father had colon cancer at age 36, and her brother was recently diagnosed with lung cancer. If genetic analysis is performed, what would be the likely genotype of this individual at the p53 tumor suppressor gene locus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) One deleted alleles Typically, cancer are precipitate by a number of “hits” or mutation/detection events that endow the transformed cell with a survival and/or growth advantage such that it is no longer restricted by the normal cellular checks and balances. The mutation events commonly include: Loss of function of both copies of a tumor suppressor gene Mutation of a proto-oncogene Fusion of a proto-oncogene with a strong promoter/enhance. p5 is a tumor suppressor gene that, when mutated or deleted, seems to play a role in many different types of cancers. If an individual inherits a mutated allele of a tumor suppressor, the chance of acquiring a second mutation in the other allele is extremely high. This second mutation “knocks-out” the normal tumor suppressor function, giving the cell a growth/survival advantage that can lead to the cancer phenotype. Member of families that are strongly predisposed to many different types of cancer may have an inherited mutant allele of p53, referred to as Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Not that although the cells of the tumor may have lost both copies of the tumor suppressor gene, analysis of the bood sample would reveal only the one mutant or deleted allele in other cells.

questions.text: A 60-years-old alcoholic with a 50 pack-year history of smoking presents with hoarseness and dysphagia. Physical examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy reveals an ulcerated nodule on the laryngeal surface. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Squamous cell carcinoma Malignant tumors of the larynx are relatively uncommon, except for those arising from surface epithelium. Most occur on the vocal cords, although they can occus cell carcinomas, which can cause hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, pain, hemoptysis, and eventually, respiratory compromise (by obstructing the airway). Ulceration can lead to superinfection. Complications arise because of direct extension, metastases, and infection. Risk factors include smoking, alcohol abuse, and chronic irritation (as might occur in singers).

questions.text: A 30-years-old womjan is diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with a previous viral infection. Which of the following viral products is (are) implicated in producing this type of dysplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) E6 and E7 proteins. Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is strongly associated with infection by high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV-16 and HPV-18. The viral proteins E6 and E7 play a central role in HPV-induced oncogenesis by disrupting the normal regulation of the cell cycle. E6 binds to and promotes the degradation of p53, a tumor suppressor protein that regulates apoptosis and prevents the propagation of damaged DNA. E7 binds to and inactivates retinoblastoma protein (pRb), another tumor suppressor that controls the cell cycle by inhibiting progression from the G1 to the S phase. By neutralizing these critical regulatory proteins, E6 and E7 promote uncontrolled cell proliferation and genomic instability, leading to the development of dysplasia and, potentially, cervical cancer. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. EBNA proteins: EBNA (Epstein-Barr nuclear antigens) proteins are associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections and contribute to the oncogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. These proteins are not implicated in HPV-related cervical dysplasia. B. E1A and E1B proteins: E1A and E1B proteins are early proteins expressed by adenoviruses, which can transform infected cells in vitro by targeting tumor suppressor pathways. However, adenoviruses are not associated with cervical dysplasia or CIN. D. Large tumor antigen: Large tumor antigen is a protein expressed by polyomaviruses such as the SV40 virus. It binds and inactivates p53 and pRb but is unrelated to HPV infection or cervical dysplasia.

choices.text: Follicular hyperplasia form of chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis
Paracortical lymphoid hyperplasia form of chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis

questions.text: A 4-years-old child with chronic tonsillitis presents with a swollen cervical lymph node. Biopsy of the node would most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Follicular hyperplasia form of chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis Chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis is a reactive lymph node hyperplasia that can take three distinct forms, seen in different clinical settings. In chronic bacterial infections, such as this patient’s chronic tonsillitis, there is a stimulation of B cells that leads to prominence of germinal centers.

questions.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix will most likely metastasize to which of the following sites?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lung. Squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix typically metastasizes to the lungs through hematogenous spread. While the primary site of cervical cancer spread is often to nearby regional lymph nodes (e.g., pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes), distant metastasis most commonly occurs to the lungs. Other organs such as the liver, bones, and brain are less commonly affected in the advanced stages of cervical squamous cell carcinoma. This makes the lung the most common site for distant metastasis in this type of cancer. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Bone: While bone metastasis can occur in advanced cervical cancer, it is much less common than metastasis to the lungs. Bone metastasis tends to occur in more advanced or widespread cancers, but in the case of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, lung involvement is more typical. B. Brain: Metastasis to the brain from cervical squamous cell carcinoma is rare. Brain metastases are more commonly associated with cancers like lung cancer, breast cancer, or melanoma. Cervical cancer tends to spread to the lungs and lymph nodes first, with brain involvement typically occurring much later, if at all. C. Kidney: The kidneys are not a common site of metastasis for cervical squamous cell carcinoma. While various cancers can metastasize to the kidneys, this is not a typical site for cervical cancer metastasis. The spread of cervical cancer to the lungs and lymph nodes is much more common.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers would most frequently be encountered in a person exposed to ionizing radiation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Leukemia Leukemia. Ionizing radiation, which is composed of electromagnetic rays (x-rays and gamma rays), and a particulate radiation including alpha particles, beta particles, protons, and neutrons are all potentially carcinogenic. Leukemias are the most frequently encountered tumors in human that have been exposed to radiation. Cancers of the breast, lung, salivary glands, and thyroid gland are in the next most frequently encountered group. Relatively uncommon in this setting are cancers of the skin, bone, and gastrointestinal tract.

choices.text: A minimum of 10% malignant osteoid production is required for a diagnosis
Metaphysis is the most common location
More common in males than in females

questions.text: Which of the following clinicopathologic features is least likely to be associated with the bone tumor shown?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A minimum of 10% malignant osteoid production is required for a diagnosis The figure shows an example of an osteosarcoma, a tumor which is composed of bone matrix-producing neoplastic cells. Any amount of neoplastic matrix, however minimal, is sufficient to categorize a tumor as an osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary nonhematopoietic malignancy of the skeletal system. It primarily affects the metaphyseal region of distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus (foci of maximum bone growth). It has a bimodal peak age of presentation. Majority of the patients are adolescents and young adults.

questions.text: All of the following childhood tumors frequently have a small round blue cell appearance on fineneedle aspiration biopsy except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Infantile fibrosarcoma Childhood soft tissue tumors with this pattern include Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, neuroblastoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common malignancy of childhood and can present as a soft tissue mass.

questions.text: Which of the following lesions is not associated with human herpes virus-8 (HHV-8) infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma. All of the above choices have been associated with HHV-8 infection, except nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which is associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection. Kaposi sarcoma herpes virus (KSHV) or human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) is a DNA virus that is causally linked to Kaposi’s sarcoma. The lesion is characterized by proliferation of spindle cells that form slit-like vascular spaces. Extravasation of red cells, chronic inflammatory cells, and hyaline globules, are associated with this lesion. This proliferation is driven by a variety of cytokines produced by mesenchymal cells infected by KSHV or HIV-infected CD4+ T-lymphocytes. There are four subtypes of Kaposi’s sarcoma: chronic/classic, transplant-associated, lymphadenopathic, and AIDS associated (epidemic). Grossly, the lesion progresses through three stages: early-macule/patch, intermediate-plaque, and late nodule/tumor. The lesional cells often express the lymphatic marker D2-40 and vascular marker FLI-1.

questions.text: All of the following represent examples of defective DNA repair syndromes except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Li–Fraumeni syndrome Xeroderma pigmentosum, ataxia-telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome, and Fanconi anemia are all autosomal-recessive syndromes that are associated with defects in DNA repair mechanisms. Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer syndrome is associated with abnormalities in the MSH-2, MLH-1, and MSH-6 genes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has a 3 cm pancreatic body mass that is biopsied.All of the following immunohistochemical stains would be positive in this tumor except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Beta-catenin (nuclear) The photomicrograph demonstrates a well-differentiated pancreatic endocrine neoplasm, characterized by ribbon-like and acinar arrangements of monotonous polygonal cells with salt and pepper chromatin.Pancreatic endocrine tumors will be positive with immunohistochemical stains for neuroendocrine markers,such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, and some epithelial markers, including low molecular weight cytokeratins. Nuclear staining for β-catenin is not a feature of pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. Rather, nuclear staining for β-catenin is suggestive of a solid pseudopapillary tumor, which can also be positive for neuroendocrine markers. beta catenin positive for solid pseudopapillary tumor of pancreas aka Grubber Frantz tumor

choices.text: Indicative of an underlying visceral malignancy

questions.text: A scaling,ulcerated lesion develops on the forearm of a 45-year-old fisherman. Excisional biopsy is performed,and the histologic appearance is similar to that shown in the figure. Which of the following is most applicable to this lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The lesion shown in the figure is a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma demonstrating sheets of neoplastic epidermal cells with keratin“pearls, ”a very common skin tumor. There is a marked predilection for sun-exposed areas, and most lesions occur on the lower part of the face or the back of the hands. Metastasis occurs in fewer than 5% of cases, because most of these lesions are discovered early and are cured by ablative therapy.
